facts.text: Appellant appointed on June 11, 1949 as officiating Assistant Director Grade II in the office of the Textile Commissioner, Bombay; appointment temporary and liable to termination on one month's notice.
Appellant posted in Textile Commissioner's office at Ahmedabad and continued to work there till February 1954.
Appellant transferred to Bombay in February 1954.

On December 29, 1953, appellant called upon to explain certain irregularities (punctuality, absenting without intimation, irregular mileage claims, unmade visit to mill, general unsatisfactory work and conduct) and state why disciplinary action should not be taken; explanation to be submitted by January 6, 1954.
Certain enquiries held against appellant behind his back after December 29, 1953 memo, but not pursued.
Informed in August 1954 that services would be terminated from September 15, 1954; no cause assigned, no opportunity to show cause.

Appellant brought suit in City Civil Court at Bombay claiming termination unjustifiable and malicious due to Regional Director's animosity; claimed quasi-permanent under CCS Temporary Service Rules 1949, entitled to Art. 311 protection, r.5 invalid under Art.16, discriminatory.

Union of India defended: appellant not quasi-permanent, r.5 applied properly as temporary employee, work and conduct unsatisfactory, transferred to Bombay to give chance of improvement, departmental inquiry not pursued as evidence inconclusive.
Trial court dismissed suit; Bombay High Court dismissed appeal on December 23, 1960; certificate granted for Supreme Court appeal.
Appellant in service more than three years by 1954, but no declaration under r.3(ii) issued.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant was a quasi-permanent employee and r.5 of the Rules did not apply to him.
Whether r.5 was invalid as hit by Art.16 of the Constitution and whether action taken against appellant was discriminatory under Art.16.
Whether appellant, even as temporary servant, entitled to protection of Art.311(2) in the circumstances.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant quasi-permanent under r.3 as in continuous service >3 years (reading sub-clauses disjunctively with 'or') or declaration; entitled to r.6 and Art.311(2) protection, not complied with.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949 r.3; Art.311(2)

petitioner_arguments.text: r.5 invalid as hit by Art.16; termination discriminatory as juniors with lesser qualifications retained.
Memo Dec 29, 1953 amounted to charge-sheet starting formal inquiry; termination punitive, requires Art.311(2).

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant not quasi-permanent; r.3 sub-clauses conjunctive (both conditions required); r.5 applies to temporary employee.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949 r.3, r.5

respondent_arguments.text: r.5 valid, not discriminatory; classification into permanent/temporary/quasi-permanent reasonable.
Termination under r.5 due to unsatisfactory work/conduct after transfer; preliminary inquiry dropped, no formal departmental inquiry; not punitive.

court_reasoning.text: r.3 sub-clauses must be read conjunctively ('and') not disjunctively; both continuous service >3 years and declaration required; scheme of rules (r.2(b), r.4-10) confirms declaration sine qua non for quasi-permanent status.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No declaration issued; appellant remains temporary under r.5.

court_reasoning.text: r.5 not hit by Art.16; reasonable classification of employees (permanent, quasi-permanent, temporary); temporary nature justifies simpler termination.
Termination not discriminatory; based on appellant's unsatisfactory conduct/work, not retrenchment; no need to terminate all with issues.

Art.311(2) applies only to punitive dismissal/removal/reduction; termination under r.5 not punitive if per contract/rules, motive irrelevant; preliminary inquiry (memo Dec 1953) not formal departmental inquiry, dropped, transfer given chance, later termination neutral.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No stigma or evil consequences; distinguishes formal vs preliminary inquiry.

holdings.text: Appellant not quasi-permanent; r.3 requires both conditions conjunctively.
r.5 valid under Art.16; termination not discriminatory.
No protection under Art.311(2); termination under r.5, not punitive.

precedents_cited.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Tests for when termination is punitive (right to post or evil consequences); motive irrelevant if under contract/rules.

precedents_cited.case_name: K.S. Srinivasan v. Union of India
B.M. Pandit v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: r.3 sub-clauses conjunctive; no 'and' or 'or' in gazette.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shyamlal v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Preliminary inquiry/explanation not triggering Art.311(2) if no formal punishment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Madan Gopal v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Formal charges, inquiry, report led to punitive termination despite 'terminate' wording.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bihar v. Gopi Kishore Prasad
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.311 applies if government purports to act under it but fails procedure.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Narayan Das v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguishes Gopi Kishore; preliminary not formal inquiry.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jagadish Mitter v. Union of India

statutes_cited.name: Central Civil Services (Temporary Service) Rules, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines quasi-permanent service, requires declaration for status, allows termination of temporary service on notice/pay in lieu; appellant governed by r.5.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.16 not violated by r.5 classification; Art.311(2) not applicable to non-punitive termination under rules.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the termination of appellant's temporary services under r.5 of CCS Temporary Service Rules 1949; held appellant not quasi-permanent, r.5 valid and non-discriminatory, no violation of Art.311(2) as termination not punitive.

key_quotes.text: "A Government servant shall be deemed to be in quasi-permanent service-- (i) if he has been in continuous Government service for more than three years (ii) if the appointing authority... has issued a declaration..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes r.3, central to interpreting conjunctive reading.

key_quotes.text: "the two sub-clauses should be read conjunctively and that two conditions are necessary before a government servant can be deemed to be in quasi-permanent service"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "whether the servant had a right to the post or the rank or (2) whether he has been visited with evil consequences"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Tests from Parshotam Lal Dhingra for Art.311 applicability.

key_quotes.text: "the motive or the inducing factor which influences the Government to take action under the terms of the contract of employment or the specific service rule is wholly irrelevant."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why preliminary inquiry does not trigger Art.311.
